trainingZones.title: Training Zones
trainingZones.masHint: Your Maximal Aerobic Speed in km/h
trainingZones.emptyState: Enter your MAS above to calculate your training zones.
trainingZones.hrEmptyState: Enter your max and resting heart rate to calculate your zones.

easy.name: E — Easy
easy.description: Comfortable conversational pace. Builds aerobic base and promotes recovery.

marathon.name: M — Marathon
marathon.description: Goal marathon race pace. Develops running economy at sustained effort.

threshold.name: T — Threshold
threshold.description: Comfortably hard. Improves lactate clearance and raises anaerobic threshold.

interval.name: I — Interval
interval.description: Hard effort at VO₂max intensity. Develops maximal aerobic capacity.

repetition.name: R — Repetition
repetition.description: Very fast, short reps. Improves running economy, speed and neuromuscular efficiency.

zone1.name: Zone 1 — Recovery
zone1.description: Very easy effort. Active recovery, warm-up and cool-down.

zone2.name: Zone 2 — Aerobic base
zone2.description: Comfortable aerobic effort. Primary fat-burning zone, builds endurance.

zone3.name: Zone 3 — Tempo
zone3.description: Moderate to hard effort. Improves aerobic efficiency and lactate threshold.

zone4.name: Zone 4 — Threshold
zone4.description: Hard effort near anaerobic threshold. Increases speed and race pace endurance.

zone5.name: Zone 5 — VO₂max
zone5.description: Maximum effort. Develops maximal oxygen uptake and speed.

perfPrediction.title: Performance Prediction
perfPrediction.modelDanielsDescription: VDOT formula — physiologically grounded, based on VO₂max & running economy.
perfPrediction.modelRiegelDescription: Power-law formula T2 = T1 × (D2/D1)^1.06 — simple and widely used.

settings.title: Settings
settings.masHint: Your Maximal Aerobic Speed — used as default in Training Zones and Split Times.
settings.refPerfHint: Used to pre-fill the Performance Prediction page.
settings.hrMaxHint: Your maximum heart rate — used in Heart Rate zones.
settings.hrRestingHint: Your resting heart rate (measured in the morning).

intervalCalc.title: Interval Calculator
intervalCalc.emptyState: Enter your MAS, % and number of reps to calculate your interval session.

vdotTraining.title: VDOT Training Paces
vdotTraining.subtitle: Jack Daniels training paces derived from your VDOT.
vdotTraining.emptyState: Enter a reference performance or a VDOT to calculate your training paces.

splitTable.emptyState: Enter values above to see split times.

predictionTable.emptyState: Enter a reference performance above to see predictions.

notFound.title: Page not found
notFound.body: The page you're looking for doesn't exist.

onboarding.title: Set up your profile
onboarding.body: Enter your MAS / VMA in Settings to pre-fill Training Zones and Split Times.

credits.title: Credits & References
credits.intro: PaceTool uses established scientific models. Here are the sources.
credits.vdotBody: Performance prediction and training pace zones are based on the Daniels-Gilbert VDOT formula, which estimates VO₂max from race performances and derives equivalent training intensities.
credits.vdotRef: Daniels J, Gilbert J. Oxygen Power: Performance Tables for Distance Runners. 1979.
credits.vdotRef2: Daniels J. Daniels' Running Formula (3rd ed.). Human Kinetics, 2014.
credits.riegelBody: The Riegel model predicts race times across distances using the power-law formula T₂ = T₁ × (D₂/D₁)^1.06.
credits.riegelRef: Riegel P.S. Athletic Records and Human Endurance. American Scientist, 69(3), 285–290. 1981.
credits.karvonenBody: Heart rate training zones are computed using the Karvonen method (Heart Rate Reserve), which accounts for both maximum and resting heart rate.
credits.karvonenRef: Karvonen M, Kentala E, Mustala O. The effects of training on heart rate. Ann Med Exp Biol Fenn. 1957;35(3):307–15.
credits.borgBody: The Borg scale (6–20) is the original Rating of Perceived Exertion scale, where the numbers loosely correspond to heart rate ÷ 10.
credits.borgRef: Borg G. Perceived exertion as an indicator of somatic stress. Scand J Rehab Med. 1970;2(2):92–8.
credits.rpeBody: The simplified 1–10 RPE scale is derived from Borg's work and widely used in modern coaching for its intuitive nature.
credits.rpeRef: Foster C et al. A New Approach to Monitoring Exercise Training. J Strength Cond Res. 2001;15(1):109–115.
credits.masBody: Training zones expressed as a percentage of MAS (Maximal Aerobic Speed / Vitesse Maximale Aérobie) are standard in French athletic coaching methodology.
credits.masRef: Billat V. Use of blood lactate measurements for prediction of exercise performance. Sports Med. 1996;22(3):157–175.
credits.openSource: This application is an independent open-source project. No affiliation with any of the cited authors or publishers.

cookieBanner.message: We use cookies to save your preferences (language, unit, MAS) locally on your device. No tracking or advertising cookies are used.

legal.privacyIntro: PaceTool is committed to protecting your privacy.
legal.privacyDataBody: This site does not collect any personal data. Your preferences (language, unit, MAS) are stored exclusively in your browser's localStorage and never transmitted to any server.
legal.privacyCookiesBody: We use functional cookies to save your preferences and, with your consent, Google Analytics cookies to measure audience (anonymised data, no advertising use).
legal.privacyThirdBody: If you accept cookies, anonymised usage data is shared with Google Analytics (Google LLC, USA). No data is shared with any other third party. Google Analytics is configured with IP anonymisation enabled and advertising signals disabled.
legal.privacyRightsBody: You can delete your stored preferences at any time by clearing your browser's localStorage or using the browser's developer tools.
legal.termsIntro: By using PaceTool, you agree to the following terms.
legal.termsServiceBody: PaceTool provides running tools (pace converter, split times, training zones, performance prediction) free of charge. Calculations are provided for informational purposes only and do not constitute medical or professional coaching advice.
legal.termsAccuracyBody: Prediction models (Jack Daniels VDOT, Riegel) are based on scientific formulas but results may differ from actual performance. Always listen to your body.
legal.termsAvailabilityBody: The service is provided as-is, without any guarantee of uptime or continuity.
legal.cookiesIntro: This policy explains how PaceTool uses cookies and similar browser storage.
legal.cookiesWhatBody: We store a single item in localStorage under the key 'running-calculator:settings' containing your language, unit preference, and MAS value. This data never leaves your device.
legal.cookiesControlBody: You can decline storage at any time using the cookie banner. You can also clear stored data via your browser settings (Application → Local Storage).
legal.cookiesAnalyticsBody: With your consent, we use Google Analytics 4 to measure audience anonymously (pages visited, session duration). IP anonymisation is enabled. This data is transmitted to Google LLC (USA) and is subject to Google's privacy policy. No advertising use is made of this data.
legal.cookiesNoTrackBody: We do not use any advertising or retargeting cookies.

rpe2.name: 2 — Very easy
rpe2.description: Very light effort. Can be maintained for hours.

rpe4.name: 4 — Moderate
rpe4.description: Somewhat easy. Breathing slightly heavier but comfortable.

rpe5.name: 5 — Moderate–Hard
rpe5.description: Moderate effort. Conversation possible but requires focus.

rpe7.name: 7 — Very Hard
rpe7.description: Very hard. Only a few words possible.

rpe8.name: 8 — Extremely Hard
rpe8.description: Extremely hard. Barely able to speak.

rpe9.name: 9 — Near Maximum
rpe9.description: Near maximal effort. Almost impossible to continue.

borg7.name: 7 — Extremely light
borg7.description: Very gentle movement. Barely perceptible effort.

borg9.name: 9 — Very light
borg9.description: Easy walking at a slow pace. Very little effort.

borg10.description: Light activity. Comfortable for a long time.

borg13.name: 13 — Somewhat hard
borg13.description: Vigorous effort. Somewhat hard, but can continue.

borg15.name: 15 — Hard
borg15.description: Hard effort. Difficult to hold a conversation.

borg16.description: Very hard effort. Only a few words possible.

borg18.description: Extremely hard. Very close to maximum.

zone1.name: Zone 1 — Recovery
zone1.description: Very easy effort. Active recovery, warm-up, cool-down.

zone2.name: Zone 2 — Aerobic
zone2.description: Comfortable conversational pace. Builds aerobic base.

zone4.name: Zone 4 — Threshold
zone4.description: Hard effort. Race-pace for long distances.

zone5.name: Zone 5 — VO2max
zone5.description: Very hard. Develops maximal aerobic capacity.
